credentials: PHD 1973 Univ of Michigan at Ann Arbor
name: TOM YIN

ratings.comment: NTP 524 is no joke- 3 exams contribute to 90% of your grade. An A is definitely possible with the extra credit opportunities! Be sure to actually understand the neural mechanisms underlying each motor/sensory/cognitive pathway. Exams are roughly 50% MC/ 50% essay. Tough class, but very interesting topics!! Unfortunate that Tom is retiring.
So sad Tom Yin has decided to retire. His lectures were thought-provoking and inspirational. I will never forget how difficult the tests were.

I won't lie, the class is really tough. BUT the content is incredibly interesting. Slides and notes are available to buy for cheap. Dont always align with lecture perfectly, but they are helpful. Don't buy textbook. 12 essays are given ahead of time, 3 are on exam. Get together with a ton of people and make a google doc. Must work hard to get an A.

Course isn't structured very well at all. Course modules provided are rough to say the least, and tests are ridiculously specific. I liked the content of the class, but very much disliked how it was taught and organized. Has potential to be a great class, but structure isn't really there.

Great professor.  Clearly interested in the subject and excited to teach so that the students will grow to love the material too.  Sometimes lectures can drag on a bit, but he provides course notes and powerpoints as well as recommended reading to supplement the lecture.  The recommended reading was very helpful in clarifying the lecture material.

Tom is a great professor who really wants you to succeed (as long as your willing to put in the effort). Class def requires work and studying, and there are two labs throughout the semester. Some how I came out with an A in the class but it did require A LOT of work. If neuro is your thing you'll find it very interesting!

Class is taught with 2 professors and 1 TA. The grading scale isn't too bad. He gets generous with the grades at the end of the semester if everyone is doing really bad. Exams are half essay, half MC. His multiple choice questions are ridiculously hard. He gives the essay questions beforehand so you can prepare for them. All in all, good class.

Very good teacher but very hard class. Be ready to suffer long nights. Exams are usually 3 15 pt. essays (45 pts) and about 55 pts of super hard multiple choice (you pick the false choice; 4 true, 1 false). Gives you list of 12 possible essays ahead of time. Class is not curved, straight up.

My favorite course in 4 years at UW: he is a great professor (smart, funny, entertaining, expects a lot out of you) who presents the material in a way that you don't mind working your a** off for his difficult but fair exams.  Lots of extra stuff on the course website. Much more difficult than 523 though. Don't miss this course!

this is a class of superlatives: it is the most interesting, exciting and most difficult class that i've taken in my 4 years here.  Tom is a great teacher who motivates you to work hard so you don't mind spending hours preparing for his exceptionally thought-provoking exams.  loved the class!!

very interesting class! He's a great teacher. The down side is that notes are frustrating to study. Information about one part of the brain can be scattered among 3 different parts of the notes, each telling you something different.

He's great!  He makes the course very interesting and engaging.  His tests can be tricky, but if you study your notes you'll be more than fine.  He's a good teacher, but be prepared to study for his class.
